title: Tomás Mejía Camacho
text:
José Tomás de la Luz Mejía Camacho, better known as Tomás Mejía (September 17, 1820 – June 19, 1867), was a Mexican soldier. He was of <a href="Otomi">Otomi</a> <a href="Indigenous%20peoples%20of%20Mexico">indigenous</a> origin and came from a humble background, studying in the local rural school. He was a loyal <a href="Catholic%20Church">Catholic</a> siding with the <a href="Conservative%20Party%20%28Mexico%29">conservatives</a> during the <a href="Reform%20War">Reform War</a> and later the <a href="Second%20French%20intervention%20in%20Mexico">Second French intervention</a>.
Service.
Born in <a href="Pinal%20de%20Amoles">Pinal de Amoles</a>, <a href="Sierra%20Gorda">Sierra Gorda</a>, <a href="Quer%C3%A9taro">Querétaro</a>, Mejía served in the <a href="Mexican%20Army">Mexican Army</a> from 1841 to 1867, fought against the Americans in the <a href="Mexican%E2%80%93American%20War">Mexican–American War</a> where he distinguished himself at the <a href="Battle%20of%20Buena%20Vista">Battle of Buena Vista</a>. He sided with the conservatives during the Reform War in opposition to the <a href="separation%20of%20church%20and%20state">separation of church and state</a> during <a href="Liberal%20Party%20%28Mexico%29">liberal</a> reforms. After the war was lost, he fought as a cavalry general on the side of <a href="Emperor%20of%20Mexico">Emperor</a> <a href="Maximilian%20I%20of%20Mexico">Maximilian I of Mexico</a> during the war between monarchists and republicans after the Second French intervention in 1862 and the rise of the <a href="Second%20Mexican%20Empire">Second Mexican Empire</a> in 1863–1864. Overall, Mejía would wage guerilla war in the region of Sierra Gorda around eight years.
Eventually, the war was lost with the French, conservatives, and imperialists retreating. The general was surrounded with the emperor <a href="Siege%20of%20Quer%C3%A9taro">at Querétaro City</a> where the months of being besieged led to a republican victory in 1867. Afterwards, he was <a href="Execution%20by%20firing%20squad">executed by firing squad</a>, together with General <a href="Miguel%20Miram%C3%B3n">Miguel Miramón</a> and Emperor Maximilian I, at the <a href="Cerro%20de%20las%20Campanas">Cerro de las Campanas</a> in the outskirts of <a href="Quer%C3%A9taro%20City">Querétaro City</a>, ending the Second Mexican Empire along with the conservative cause.
Decorations.
Mejía was awarded <a href="Mexican%20Imperial%20Orders%23Imperial%20Order%20of%20Guadalupe">Grand Cross of the Imperial Order of Guadalupe</a> in 1864 and <a href="Mexican%20Imperial%20Orders%23Imperial%20Order%20of%20the%20Mexican%20Eagle">Grand Cross of the Imperial Order of the Mexican Eagle</a> in 1865.
